revisions.rev:
{{lead too long|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox software | name = App Store | title = | logo = | screenshot = [[File:Apple Store.jpg|250px]] | caption = Screenshot of the desktop App Store in [[iTunes]]. | collapsible = | author = | developer = [[Apple Inc.]] | released = {{Start date and age|2008|07|10}} | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | programming language = | operating system = [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]],
[[Mac OS X Tiger]] or later
[[Windows XP]] or later. | platform = [[iPhone]], [[iPod touch]], [[iPad]] | size = | language = | status = Active | genre = [[Digital distribution]], [[Software update]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] [[freeware]] | website = {{URL|http://www.apple.com/itunes}} }} The '''App Store''' is a digital [[Application software|application]] [[Digital distribution|distribution]] platform for [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] developed and maintained by [[Apple Inc.]] The service allows users to browse and download [[mobile apps|applications]] from the [[iTunes Store]] that were developed with the [[iOS SDK]] or Mac SDK and published through Apple Inc.. Depending on the application, they are available either for free or at a cost. The applications can be downloaded directly to a target device, or downloaded onto a [[Personal computer|PC]] or [[Macintosh|Mac]] via [[iTunes]]. 30% of revenue from the store go to Apple, and 70% go to the producer of the app.[http://venturebeat.com/2008/06/11/analyst-thees-a-great-future-in-iphone-apps/ "Analyst: Thereâs a great future in iPhone apps"], Venture Beat, June 11, 2008. The App Store opened on July 10, 2008 via an update to iTunes. On July 11, the iPhone 3G was launched and came pre-loaded with iOS 2.0.1 with App Store support; new iOS 2.0.1 firmware for iPhone and iPod Touch was also made available via iTunes.{{cite web |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/06/09iphone.html |title=Apple Introduces the New iPhone 3G |publisher=Apple |date=2008-06-09 |accessdate=2009-09-16}} As of June 6, 2011, there are at least 425,000 third-party apps officially available on the App Store. As of January 18, 2011, the App Store had over 9.9 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] downloads, which was announced via the company's "10 Billion App Countdown".[http://www.apple.com/itunes/10-billion-app-countdown/ "10 Billion App Countdown"] Apple 2011-01-14. At 10:26 AM GMT on Saturday, January 22, 2011,[http://www.setteb.it/?p=10452 10:26 AM GMT on Saturday, January 22, 2011] setteB.IT 2011-01-22. the 10 billionth app was downloaded from Apple App Store. At early July 2011, 200 million iOS users have downloaded over 15 billion apps from its App Store.http://techcrunch.com/2011/07/07/apples-app-store-crosses-15b-app-downloads-adds-1b-downloads-in-past-month/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Techcrunch+%28TechCrunch%29 The [[mean]] revenue per application is estimated to be [[United States dollar|US$]]8,700, although data is not publicly available.{{cite web |url=http://communities-dominate.blogs.com/brands/2010/06/full-analysis-of-iphone-economics-its-bad-news-and-then-it-gets-worse.html |title=Full Analysis of iPhone Economics - it is bad news. And then it gets worse |publisher=Communities Dominate Brands |date=2010-06-22}} As of May 2011, Apple approved its 500,000th app and 37 percent of all apps are free with the average price $3.64.http://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_technews/20110524/tc_yblog_technews/apple-approves-its-500000th-app-but-do-you-care The distribution of price follows a power law distribution (the [[ZipfâMandelbrot law]]). Prices can be freely chosen by sellers at multiple of US$1 minus 1 cent (99Â¢, $1.99, and so on). After the success of Apple's App Store, and the launch of [[list of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices|similar services]] by its competitors, the term "app store" has been adopted to refer to any similar service for mobile devices.{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idUSTRE53L5DK20090422 |title=In app store war, BlackBerry, Google hold own |publisher=Reuters |date=22 April 2009 |first=Sinead|last=Carew |accessdate=23 June 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://gadgetwise.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/29/nokias-app-store-launches-with-a-hiccup/ |title=Nokiaâs App Store Launches With a Hiccup |publisher=The New York Times |date=29 May 2009 |first=Roy|last=Furchgott |accessdate=23 June 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2009/03/blackberry-app/ |title=BlackBerry App Store Gets a Name |publisher=''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' |date=4 March 2009 |first=Priya|last=Ganapati |accessdate=23 June 2009 }}{{cite news|last=Shiels |first=Maggie |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8157043.stm |title=Technology | Apps 'to be as big as internet' |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-07-20 |accessdate=2009-12-02}} However, Apple applied for a trademark on the term ''App Store'' in 2008 {{cite web |title= Apple files for MacRuby, App Store & Finder trademarks|url=http://www.macnn.com/blogs/2008/07/22/apple-files-for-macruby-app-store-finder-trademarks.html|publisher=[[MacNN]] |date=22 July 2008 |accessdate=27 Aug 2009}} {{cite web |title= Trademark application|url=http://tarr.uspto.gov/tarr?regser=serial&entry=77%2F525433&action=Request+Status|publisher=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=18 Apr 2011}} which was tentatively approved in 2011 .{{cite web |title=How Apple Can Trademark 'App Store'|url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2382968,00.asp|publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |date=1 Apr 2011 |accessdate=18 Apr 2011}} Later, in June 2011, U.S. District Judge Phyllis Hamilton, who is presiding over Apple's case against Amazon, said she'll "probably" deny Apple's motion that seeks to bar the Web retailer from using the "App Store" name.http://news.cnet.com/8301-27076_3-20073524-248/judge-likely-to-deny-apples-appstore-complaint/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-22/apple-bid-to-bar-amazon-appstore-will-likely-be-denied.html{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/22/us-apple-amazon-idUSTRE75L79Y20110622 | work=Reuters | title=Apple may have tough road in Amazon lawsuit | date=2011-06-22}} Later on July 6th, Apple was denied preliminary injunction against [[Amazon Appstore|Amazon's Appstore]] by a federal judge.http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/07/apples-preliminary-injunction-against-amazons-appstore-denied.ars The term ''app'' has become a popular [[buzzword]]; in January 2011, ''app'' was awarded the honor of being 2010's "Word of the Year" by the [[American Dialect Society]]."[http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gO_3DHeXRb-b1CJCbGjRCUK1vVgQ?docId=1635c27d508b451396e873660a279cd6. Linguists vote 'app' Word of the Year"]. The Associated Press. 2011-01-07. Retrieved 2011-01-27. Apple does not hold a trademark on, or claim exclusive rights to the term ''app,'' which has been used as shorthand for "application" since at least 2002, for example [[Google Apps]] (first introduced in 2006).http://www.google.co.uk/#q=app+-application&hl=en&lr=&sa=X&rls=com.microsoft:en-us&tbs=cdr:1,cd_min:1/1/1998,cd_max:31/12/2007&fp=1&cad=b On October 20, 2010, Apple announced the [[Mac App Store]] which was eventually launched on January 7, 2011. It is similar to the one for iOS devices, only it has applications designed for Mac computers.[http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20020208-56.html Apple unveils new MacBook Airs, previews Lion | Beyond Binary - CNET News] The Mac App Store is only accessible by using [[Mac OS X Snow Leopard]] or [[Mac OS X Lion]]. The App Store is accessible from the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad via an [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] application by the same name. It is also the only way to directly download native applications onto an iOS device without [[iOS jailbreaking|jailbreaking]] the device. Web applications can be installed on these devices, bypassing the App Store entirely, but they tend to have less functionality. The store is also accessible through iTunes, and then on any [[operating system]] for which iTunes is provided ([[Mac OS X]] and [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]{{cite web |title=iTunes Download site| url=http://www.apple.com/itunes/download/accessdate=26 February 2011}}). In February 2011, Apple announced its new subscription based service which will allow publishers to set the length and price of a subscription. Previously, new magazine or news releases would be sold on a per release basis. The new service allows publishers to sell their content through their apps allowing users to receive the new content over specified period of time. More interesting is that Apple will allow publishers not only to sell from iTunes where revenue will be shared (70% for the publisher, 30% for Apple), but they are also allowing publishers to distribute their subscriptions directly from their websites where no revenue will be shared with Apple.{{cite news |title= Apple rolls out subscription service|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/tech-news/apple-rolls-out-subscription-service/article1907736/|publisher=[[Globe&Mail newspaper]] |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |location=Toronto |first=Paul |last=Thomasch}} ==iPhone SDK== {{main|iOS SDK}}
[[File:IPad App Store.png|thumb|App Store running on iPad version of iOS 4.3.5]] The [[iOS SDK|Software Development Kit for iPhone OS]] was announced at the iPhone Software Roadmap event on March 6, 2008. The SDK allows developers running [[Mac OS X 10.5|Mac OS X 10.5.4]] or higher on an Intel Mac to create applications using [[Xcode]] that will natively run on the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad. A beta version was released after the event and a final version was released in July 2008 alongside the iPhone 3G.{{cite web|author=[[Apple Inc.]] |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/03/06iphone.html |title=Apple Announces iPhone 2.0 Software Beta |publisher=Apple.com |date=2008-03-06 |accessdate=2009-12-02}} This major Roadmap event (coupled with a large distribution program for 3rd-party developers), later became known as the iPhone Developer Program, which currently offers two distribution tracks for 3rd-party developers: Standard, and Enterprise.{{cite web|author=Apple Inc. |url=http://developer.apple.com/iphone/program/distribute.html |title=iPhone Developer Program - Enterprise Distribution |publisher=Developer.apple.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-02}} Applications distributed through the standard program can be sold exclusively through the [[iTunes Store]] on Mac and Windows, or on the App Store on the iPhone, iPod Touch, and iPad. Developers who publish their applications on the App Store will receive 70% of sales revenue, and will not have to pay any distribution costs for the application. However, an annual fee is required to use the iPhone SDK and upload applications to the store. Applications developed through the enterprise program, officially the "iOS Enterprise Developer Program" (iDEP), are exclusively for institutional use and do not get published on the App Store. This allows corporations, non-profits and government agencies to develop proprietary "in-house" applications not for public release. The enterprise program was updated September 14, 2010, to allow any organization with a [[Data Universal Numbering System|DUNS number]] to join. Prior to this date, only organizations with 500 or more employees could join the enterprise program. To run an application on the iPhone, the application needs to be signed. This signed certificate is only granted by Apple after the developer has first developed the software through either the US$99/year Standard package or the US$299/year Enterprise package with the [[iPhone SDK]]. ==Number of launched applications== On July 10, 2008, Apple [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Steve Jobs]] told ''[[USA Today]]'' that the App Store contained 500 third-party applications for the iPhone and the iPod Touch, and of these 25% were free.{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2008/07/10/jobs-app-store-launching-with-500-iphone-applications-25-free/|title=Jobs: App Store launching with 500 iPhone applications, 25% free|date=2008-07-10|publisher=[[Engadget]]|accessdate=2010-06-05}} These third party applications range from business to game applications, entertainment to educational applications, and many more applications available for free or for sale. On July 11, 2008 the store opened, allowing users to buy applications and transfer them to an iPhone or iPod Touch with the iPhone 2.0 software update, which became available through [[iTunes]] on the same day. Ten million applications were downloaded the first weekend.{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/07/14appstore.html|title=iPhone App Store Downloads Top 10 Million in First Weekend|date=2008-07-14|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|work=Press Release|accessdate=2008-11-10}} On January 16, 2009, Apple announced on its website that 500 million applications had been downloaded.{{cite web|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/01/16/half_billion_iphone_apps/|title=iPhone App Store breezes past 500 million downloads|date=2009-01-16|publisher=The Register|accessdate=2009-01-24}} The billionth application was downloaded on April 23, 2009. Unlike the apps that come standard on the iPhone, apps downloaded from the App Store can be removed by the user at a future date. ===Revenue Share=== [[File:Global Mobile Applications Store Revenue.svg|Global Mobile Applications Store Revenue]] Besides downloading volumes, the App Store's relatively high revenue of US$1782 million in 2010 may be attributed to it having only 28% of free apps, in comparison to [[Android Market]]'s over 57% of free apps. As a result, both [[Nokia]]'s [[Ovi Store]] and [[BlackBerry]]'s [[App World]], both of which have only 26% free apps, also pull in higher revenues than Android Market despite having much lower downloading volumes.{{cite web |url=http://techcrunch.com/2010/07/05/distimo-june-2010/ |title=Google Android has double the number of free apps than Apple's App Store |date=15 July 2009 |publisher=[[Distimo]] |accessdate=15 July 2009}} ===Milestones=== [[Image:AppleAppStoreStatistics.png|thumb|alt=Chart showing App Store downloads and available apps over time.|App Store Apps and Downloads|200px|right|App Store application availability has increased in line with downloads over time.]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Available apps ! Downloads to date |- | July 11, 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/07/10iphone.html|title=iPhone 3G on Sale Tomorrow|date=2008-07-10|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|work=Press Release|accessdate=2009-01-17}} | 500 | 0 |- | July 14, 2008 | 800 | 10,000,000 |- | September 9, 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/09/09appstore.html|title=App Store Downloads Top 100 Million Worldwide|date=2008-09-09|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|work=Press Release|accessdate=2008-11-10}} | 3,000 | 55,000,000 |- | October 22, 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/10/21results.html|title=Apple Reports Fourth Quarter Results|date=2008-10-21|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|work=Press Release|accessdate=2009-01-17}} | 7,500 | 200,000,000 |- | January 16, 2009 | 15,000 | 500,000,000 |- | March 17, 2009 {{cite web|url=http://techcrunch.com/2009/03/17/phone-apps-hit-800-million-downloads|title=Apple Opens Up More Ways To Get Paid On The iPhone, Adds Key New Features. web|url=http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/09/28/apple_announces_app_store_downloads_top_2_billion.html|title=Appleinsider.com|date=2009-09-28|publisher=[[Appleinsider]]|accessdate=2009-09-28}} | 85,000 | 2,000,000,000 |- | November 4, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.macrumors.com/2009/11/04/apple-announces-over-100000-apps-available-on-the-app-store/ |title=Apple Announces Over 100,000 Apps Available on the App Store |publisher=Mac Rumors |date=2009-11-04 |accessdate=2009-12-02}}{{cite web|author=Apple Computer, Inc. |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2009/11/04appstore.html |title=Apple Announces Over 100,000 Apps Now Available on the App Store |publisher=Apple.com |date=2009-11-04 |accessdate=2009-12-02}} | 100,000 | 2,000,000,000+ |- | January 5, Rumors][http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2010/01/05appstore.html Appleâs App Store Downloads Top Three Billion] | 120,000 | 3,000,000,000+ |- | March 20, 2010[http://www.apple.com/ipad/app-store/ Apple - iPad - Apps for iPad] | 150,000+ | 3,000,000,000+ |- | April 8, 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.macrumors.com/2010/04/08/apples-iphone-os-4-0-media-event-sneak-peek-into-the-future/|title=Apple's iPhone OS 4.0 Media Event: 'Sneak Peek Into the Future'|author=Eric Slivka|date=April 8, 2010|accessdate=April 8, 2010|work=[[MacRumors]]}} | 185,000+ | 4,000,000,000+ |- | April 29, 2010[http://www.apple.com/hotnews/thoughts-on-flash/ Thoughts on Flash] | 200,000+ |4,500,000,000+ |- | June 7, 2010[http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/10/06/07/apple_says_app_store_has_made_developers_over_1_billion.html AppleInsider | Apple says App Store has made developers over billion] | 225,000+ | 5,000,000,000+ |- | September 1, 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-WIKvtI2Zuw|title=Apple Special Event, September 1, 2010|date=September 1, 2010|work=[[Apple]]}} | 250,000+ | 6,500,000,000+ |- | October 20, 2010 | 300,000+{{cite web|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/154980/2010/10/jobs_transcript.html|title=Jobs Speaks! The complete transcript|date=October 18, 2010|accessdate=June 11, 2011|publisher=[[Macworld]]}} | 7,000,000,000{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHllK_hKFxY|title=Apple Special Event, October 20, 2010|date=October 20, 2010|work=[[Apple]]}} |- | Jan 22, 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2011/01/22appstore.html|title=Apple's App Store Downloads Top 10 Billion|date=January 22, 2011|accessdate=January 22, 2011|work=[[Apple]]}} | 350,000+ | 10,000,000,000+ |- | June 6, 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.apple.com/apple-events/wwdc-2011/|title=Apple Special Event, June 6, 2011|date=June 6, 2011|work=[[Apple]]}} | 425,000+ | 14,000,000,000+ |- | July 7, 2011{{cite web|publisher=Apple|title=Appleâs App Store Downloads Top 15 Billion|url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2011/07/07Apples-App-Store-Downloads-Top-15-Billion.html}} | 425,000+ | 15,000,000,000+ |- |October 4, 2011 {{cite web|publisher=Apple|title=Apple Special Event October 4th 2011, release of the iPhone 4S (scroll to 22 minutes in the presentation)|url=http://events.apple.com.edgesuite.net/11piuhbvdlbkvoih10/event/index.html}} |500,000+ |18,000,000,000+ |- |} ===iPad Applications=== The iPad launched in April 2010 with over 3000 applications designed for the iPad. By December 2010, just eight months after the release of the iPad, over 50,000 apps were available for the device. As of July 2011, 16 months after the iPad launched, there are over 100,000 apps available at the App Store designed specifically for the device.[http://ipadhelp.com/ipad-news/over-100000-ipad-apps-available/|title=Over 100,000 iPad Apps Available|] On the July 7, 2011, Apple announced that over 15 billion apps had been downloaded from the iOS app store. But, micro level information on the number of downloads of each ranked application has not been made available. To help app producers with their marketing effort and help researchers in better understanding the Apple's iOS app store, a recent research study{{cite journal|publisher=SSRN|title=Estimating App Demand from Publicly Available Data|ssrn=1924044}} has tried to estimate the model that converts the app rank to daily downloads. Researchers Garg and Telang from [[Carnegie Mellon University]] found that the app downloads follow a [[Pareto distribution]] and can be estimated using the equations:
''iPad_app_downloads = 9,525 * paid_app_rank^(-0.903)
iPhone_app_downloads = 52,511 * paid_app_rank^(-0.944)''
NOTE: this claim has not been verified by Apple or any other market research organization. At the end of November 2011, Apple advertised in holiday newsletter of [[Apple Store (online)|online Apple Store]] there are more than 140,000 iPad apps available. ===Most popular apps=== In April 2009, Apple announced the apps which had the most number of downloads since the store was launched. Among paid apps, Crash Bandicoot Nitro Kart 3D, by Activision Publishing, was ranked first, while Facebook enjoyed the same position among free apps, followed by Google Earth.[http://www.mobilewebgo.com/apples-most-popular-apps-ever-announced-april-2009 Apple's most popular apps ever, announced April 2009 | Mobile Web Go] Other popular apps include [[Angry Birds]] and apps made by Ragdoll Studios. Whatsapp is the most popular app for messaging between BB, Android and iPhone. It works similar to the BB messenger. ==Application ratings== Apple rates applications worldwide based on their content, and determines what age group each is appropriate for. According to the [[iPhone OS version history|iPhone OS 3.0]] launch event, the iPhone will allow blocking of objectionable apps in the iPhone's settings. The following are the ratings that Apple has detailed: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rating ! Description |- | style="text-align: center;"|'''4+''' | Contains no objectionable material. |- | style="text-align: center;"|'''9+''' | May contain mild or infrequent occurrences of cartoon, fantasy or realistic violence, and infrequent or mild mature, suggestive, or horror-themed content which may not be suitable for children under the age of 9. |- | style="text-align: center;"|'''12+''' | May also contain infrequent mild language, frequent or intense cartoon, fantasy or realistic violence, and mild or infrequent mature or suggestive themes, and simulated gambling which may not be suitable for children under the age of 12. |- | style="text-align: center;"|'''17+''' | May also contain frequent and intense mature, horror, and suggestive themes; plus strong sexual content, nudity, strong language, alcohol, tobacco, and drugs which may not be suitable for children under the age of 17. Also, if the app accesses the internet it is rated 17+. Consumers must be at least 17 years old to purchase apps with this rating. Whenever an app of this rating is requested for download, a message will appear, verifying if a user is 17 or older, and asking to confirm the purchase for this reason. |} ==App approval process== {{Main|Approval of iOS apps}} Applications are subject to approval by Apple, as outlined in the SDK agreement, for basic reliability testing and other analysis. Applications may still be distributed "ad-hoc" if they are rejected, by the author manually submitting a request to Apple to license the application to individual iPhones, although Apple may withdraw the ability for authors to do this at a later date. [[Non-disclosure agreement]]s (NDA) have always forbidden developers from publishing the content of their rejection notices, but Apple has now started labeling their rejection letters with Non-Disclosure (NDA) warning THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS MESSAGE IS UNDER NON-DISCLOSURE. Apple later changed the NDA citing that "it has created too much of a burden on developers" but they did not reverse the decision to forbid publication of rejection notices. Some applications are not available outside the US App Store at the request of the developer. Since so many developers have published rejection emails Apple now most often call submitters to verbally tell them their rejection notice. In addition, Apple has removed software licensed under the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) from the App Store after complaints from one of the program's developers, claiming that the App Store's terms of service are inconsistent with the GPL.Brett Smith, ''[http://www.fsf.org/blogs/licensing/more-about-the-app-store-gpl-enforcement More about the App Store GPL Enforcement]'', [[Free Software Foundation]] blog{{cite web |url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2375476,00.asp |title=Apple Pulls VLC Player from App Store Due to GPL |author=David Murphy |date=8 January 2011 |work=PCMag.com |publisher=PC Magazine |accessdate=8 January 2011}} ==Enterprise App Stores== Because Apple's App Store is for consumers, companies are unable to distribute in-house apps on the App Store. Under Apple's iOS Developer Enterprise Program companies can publish in-house apps using an ''Enterprise App Store''{{cite web|url=http://www.cio.com/article/638175/Emerging_Tech_Alternatives_to_Apple_App_Store_For_Enterprises |title=Emerging Tech: Alternatives to Apple App Store, For Enterprises |publisher=cio.com |date=2011-11-19 |accessdate= }} with systems such as [[Apperian]] EASE{{cite web|url=http://www.apperian.com/ease |title=Enterprise App Services Environment |publisher=apperian.com |date= |accessdate= }} or a Mobile Device Management platform such as [http://www.sybase.com/products/mobileenterprise/afaria Sybase Afaria]. Apps published with Apple's iOS Developer Enterprise Program are still subject to Apple's control via the controversial kill switch,{{cite web|url=http://advice.cio.com/tom_kaneshige/14415/apple_iphone_kill_switch_can_cios_trust_apple |title=Apple iPhone Kill Switch: Can CIOs Trust Apple? |publisher=cio.com |date=2011-11-15 |accessdate= }} where Apple can revoke a publisher's digital certificate and thereby "kill" the app on user devices. However, there is no evidence that this has been done in the enterprise environment. ==Similar services for other devices== {{Main|List of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices}} Competitors also have their own stores for mobile applications. [[Palm Inc]]. published an application store similar to the App Store for Palm devices{{cite web|url=http://appstore.pocketgear.com/palm/ |title=The Palm Software Store has gone mobile |publisher=Appstore.pocketgear.com |date=2009-01-31 |accessdate=2009-12-02}} and announced the [[Palm App Catalog|App Catalog]] for [[webOS]] on the [[Palm Pre]] that was released on June 6, 2009. Another platform, [[Android Market]] is used in conjunction with [[Google|Google's]] [[Android (operating system)|Android]] operating system. [[Microsoft]] has released [[Windows Phone Marketplace]], an application store for their [[Windows Phone]] platform. [[Nokia]] has released The "[[Ovi (Nokia)#Ovi Store|Ovi Store]]"{{cite web|url=http://store.ovi.com/ |title=Ovi Store |publisher=Store.ovi.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-02}} (which replaced its earlier "Download!" application, which predated Apple's App Store) for its [[S60]] and [[Series 40|S40]] based mobile devices. [[Samsung]] has created [[Samsung Apps]], primarily to cater for its own [[Bada OS]], but also with support for certain other Samsung devices. [[Research in Motion|RIM]] also launched its application store [[BlackBerry App World]].{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-10188400-1.html |title=RIM store crowned BlackBerry App World |publisher=[[CNet]] |date=2009-03-04 |accessdate=2009-03-08}} The [[Nintendo DSi]] is able to connect to an online store called the "DSi Shop", along with [[Sony|Sony's]] [[PlayStation Portable]] (PSP) being able to connect to [[PlayStation Store]] to download games, etc. The [[Nintendo 3DS]] also has its own application distribution platform, called the [[Nintendo eShop]]. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.itunes.com/appstore/ The App Store on iTunes] (requires iTunes) *[http://itunes.apple.com/en/genre/mobile-software-applications/id36?mt=8 App Store Downloads] (iTunes not needed) *[http://www.apple.com/iphone/appstore/ Official website on Apple.com] *[http://developer.apple.com/iphone/program/ Official iPhone developer site] *[http://iosappstats.com/ Realtime App Store Stats by country, genre and segment] *[http://jailbreakarena.com/ iOS Jailbreak] {{iOS}} {{iPhone}} {{iPod}} {{Apple}} {{Digital distribution platforms}} {{DEFAULTSORT:App Store (Ios)}} [[Category:Apple Inc. services]] [[Category:IPhone]] [[Category:IPad]] [[Category:IOS software]] [[Category:ITunes]] [[ar:ÙØªØ¬Ø± Ø§ÙØªØ·Ø¨ÙÙØ§Øª]] [[ca:App Store]] [[cs:App Store]] [[da:App Store]] [[de:App Store]] [[es:App Store]] [[fr:App Store]] [[ko:ì± ì¤í ì´]] [[is:App Store]] [[it:App Store]] [[he:App Store]] [[hu:App Store]] [[nl:App Store]] [[ja:App Store]] [[no:App Store]] [[pl:App Store]] [[pt:App Store (iOS)]] [[ru:App Store]] [[simple:App Store (iOS)]] [[sl:App Store]] [[sv:Itunes Store#App Store]] [[tr:App Store]] [[uk:App Store]] [[zh:App Store]]
